Selected Answer: D
D. Waterfall is the best description of this approach when a project is created in response to a security breach and requires multiple patches to be fully compliant.

The Waterfall approach is a linear, sequential method of project management that involves completing each phase of the project before moving on to the next. It is characterized by a focus on upfront planning, clear milestones and deliverables, and a defined process for completing each phase of the project.

Selected Answer: D
The waterfall project management approach entails a clearly defined sequence of execution with project phases that do not advance until a phase receives final approval.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D. Increase the frequency of the status reports is the best way for the project manager to increase Ann's visibility on issues when Ann is concerned by how long issues remain open before being brought to her attention.

Status reports are a key tool for keeping stakeholders informed about the progress and status of a project. By increasing the frequency of the status reports, the project manager can provide more frequent and timely updates to Ann and other stakeholders about the status of issues and other key project components. This can help to ensure that issues are brought to Ann's attention more quickly and that she has the information she needs to make informed decisions about the project.

questions.answer_description: Highlighting only certain important issues shall enable Ann to keep an eye on important issues.
questions.question_text: Ann, a project sponsor, is concerned by how long issues remain open before being brought to her attention. Which of the following would be BEST way for the project manager to increase Ann's visibility on issues?

choices.D: Increase the frequency of the status reports.
choices.A: Tailor the status reports to bring only certain information forward.
choices.C: Schedule daily, face-to-face meetings with Ann.
choices.B: Provide more detail in the regular status reports.
